pages.text: Create's core power system is the concept of $(l)Rotational Force$(). Sometimes the provided rotation speed and direction affects their behavior, and some machines have a more significant $(i)cost$() than others.$(br2)The following pages will attempt to cover these concepts in a succinct way.

$(l)Stress and Capacity$()$(br2)Machines that generate rotational force have limits, called their $(o)'Stress Capacity'$(). Machines that consume rotational force are said to have a $(o)'Stress Impact'$().$(br2)A mechanical network that is $(o)overstressed$() will seize up and be unable to function until the extra load is removed, or more capacity is added.

$(l)Stressful Speed$()$(br2)Stress impact is tied to rotation speed. The faster you operate a machine, the more stress it will consume. By default, components used $(l)only for relaying$() rotational power, such as $(l:shaft)Shafts$() and $(l:cogwheel)cogwheels$() will consume $(l)zero Stress$(), allowing you to design your transmission system however you like.

Optimizing stress can become quite scientific. Create does supply equipment to examine Stress and Speed in detail, which will be covered in a later section. For those who are interested in more exhaustive information, please investigate the $(l:https://github.com/Creators-of-Create/Create/wiki)Create Wiki$().
